chapter.title: Module system and toolset
chapter.para: The Ceylon module architecture enables a toolset which relieves developers of many mundane tasks. The module system specifies:

listitem.para: the format of packaged deployable module archives and source archives,
the layout of a module repository
the format of the package descriptor files which contain information about the packages contained in a module, including whether a package is visible to other modules, and
the format of the module descriptor file which contains information about a module, along with a list of its versioned dependencies.

chapter.para: Thus, developers are never exposed to individual .class files, and are not required to manually manage module archives using the operating system file manager. Instead, the toolset helps automate the management of modules within module repositories.
Circular dependencies between modules are not supported. The Ceylon compiler detects such dependencies and produces an error.

section.title: Class loader architecture
section.para: Ceylon supports a simplified class loader architecture:

listitem.para: The bootstrap class loader owns classes required to bootstrap the module runtime. It is the direct parent of all module class loaders, and its classes are visible to all module class loaders.

A module class loader owns classes belonging to a given version of a certain module. Its classes are visible only to classes belonging to the module class loader of a module which declares an explicit dependency on the given version of the first module.

section.para: At any time, there may be multiple versions of a certain module available in the VM.

section.title: Module architecture
section.para: Compiled code is automatically packaged into module archives by the Ceylon compiler. A module repository is a repository containing module archives. A module archive is automatically obtained from a module repository when a class belonging to the module is needed by the compiler or module runtime.
Modules that form part of the Ceylon SDK are found in the module repository in the modules directory of the Ceylon distribution.

Red Hat maintains a central module repository at http://modules.ceylon-lang.org. Read access to this site is free of registration and free of charge. Ceylon projects which distribute their modules under a royalty-free license may apply for a user account which provides write access to the central module repository.
A module belonging to the central module repository must satisfy the following regulations:

listitem.para: the first element of the module name must be a top-level internet domain name, and the second element of the module name must be a second-level domain of the given top-level domain owned by the organization distributing the module, and
the module must be packaged as a module archive signed using the Java jarsigner tool.

section.para: For example, a module developed by Red Hat might be named org.jboss.server.

section.title: Module archives
section.para: A Ceylon module archive is a Java jar archive which:

listitem.para: contains a Ceylon module descriptor in the module directory,
contains the compiled .class files for all compilation units belonging to the module, and
has a filename which adheres to the standard for module archive names.

section.para: The module directory of the module archive is formed by replacing each period in the fully qualified package name with the directory separator character. For example, the module directory for the module ceylon.language is:
The module directory for the module org.hibernate is:

The package directory for a package belonging to the module archive is formed by replacing each period in the fully qualified package name with the directory separator character. For example, the package directory for the package org.hibernate.impl is:
Inside a module archive, a .class file is found in the package directory of the package to which it belongs.
Thus, the structure of the module archive for the module org.hello might be the following:
section.programlisting: org.hello-1.0.0.car META-INF/ MANIFEST.MF org/ hello/ module.class //the module descriptor main/ package.class //a package descriptor hello.class default/ DefaultHello.class personalized/ PersonalizedHello.class
section.para: A module archive may not contain multiple modules.

A module archive may be accompanied by a legacy archive. A legacy archive is a standard Java jar containing compiled classes required by the module, whose filename adheres to the standard for legacy archive names. At runtime there is no difference between a class packaged in a legacy archive and a class packaged directly in the module archive.

section.title: Source archives
section.para: A source archive is a zip archive which:

listitem.para: contains the source code (.ceylon and .java files) for all compilation units belonging to the module, and
has a filename which adheres to the standard for source archive names.

section.para: Inside a source archive, a Ceylon or Java source file is located in the package directory of the package to which the compilation unit belongs. The package directory for a package belonging to the source archive is formed by replacing each period in the fully qualified package name with the directory separator character.
Thus, the structure of the source archive for the module org.hello might be the following:
section.programlisting: org.hello-1.0.0.src org/ hello/ module.ceylon //the module descriptor main/ package.ceylon //a package descriptor hello.ceylon default/ DefaultHello.ceylon personalized/ PersonalizedHello.ceylon
section.para: A source archive may not contain the source of multiple modules.

section.title: Module repositories
section.para: A module repository is a directory structure on the local filesystem or a remote HTTP server.

listitem.para: A local module repository is identified by a filesystem path.
A remote module repository is identified by a URL with protocol http: or https:.

section.title: Package descriptors
section.para: A package descriptor is defined in a source file named package.ceylon in the package it describes.
A package may be annotated shared. A shared package is visible outside the containing module. The package descriptor is optional for unshared packages.

section.title: Module descriptors
section.para: A module descriptor is defined in a source file named module.ceylon in the root package of the module it describes (the package with the same name as the module).
The quoted literal after the module name specifies the version of the module.
A module may import other modules.
The quoted literal after the imported module name specifies the version of the imported module.
An imported module may be annotated optional and/or transitive.

section.title: Toolset
section.para: The Ceylon SDK contains the following tools:

listitem.para: the Java VM, java,
the front end for the Java VM, ceylon,
the compiler, ceylonc,
the module info tool, ceylonp,
the documentation compiler, ceylond,
the repository replicator, ceylonr, and
the source archive extractor, ceylonf.

section.title: Source directories
section.para: A source directory contains Ceylon source code in files with the extension .ceylon and Java source code in files with the extension .java. The module and package to which a compilation unit belongs is determined by the subdirectory in which the source file is found.

The name of the package to which a compilation unit belongs is formed by replacing every path directory separator character with a period in the relative path from the source directory to the subdirectory containing the source file. In the case of a Java source file, the subdirectory must agree with the package specified by the Java package declaration.

The name of the module to which a compilation unit belongs is determined by searching all containing directories for a module descriptor. The name of the module is formed by replacing every path directory separator character with a period in the relative path from the source directory to the subdirectory containing the module descriptor.
Thus, the structure of the source directory containing the module org.hello might be the following:
section.programlisting: source/ org/ hello/ module.ceylon //the module descriptor main/ hello.ceylon default/ DefaultHello.ceylon personalized/ PersonalizedHello.ceylon
section.para: The source code for multiple modules may be contained in a single source directory.

section.title: The VM front end
section.para: The ceylon command accepts the name of a module with an optional version, along with the following options:

listitem.para: -run specifies the fully qualified name of a toplevel method or class with no parameters.
-rep specifies a module repository.
-src specifies a source directory.
-d disables the default module repositories and source directory.
-help displays a usage help page.
-version specifies the Ceylon version.

section.para: The ceylon options must come first, before the module name and version. Any argument passed after the module name and version will be passed to the Ceylon module that we are running.
The default module repositories are modules and http://modules.ceylon-lang.org, and the default source directory is source.

Execution begins with the named toplevel method or class, or with the entry point specified in the module descriptor, and imported modules are loaded lazily as classes they contain are needed. The name and version id of the imported module containing the needed class are determined from the imported package name specified by the compilation unit and the imported module version specified by the module descriptor.

Each version of each module is loaded using a different class loader. Classes inside a module have access to other classes in the same module and to classes belonging to modules that are explicitly imported in the module descriptor. Classes in other modules are not accessible.
The module runtime searches for modules in the following locations:

listitem.para: module archives in the specified repositories,
source archives in the specified repositories, and
module directories in the specified source directories.

section.para: If no version identifier is specified for a module, the module is assumed to exist in a source directory.
Source code in source archives and source directories is automatically compiled by the module runtime.

section.title: The compiler
section.para: The Ceylon compiler is able to compile Ceylon and Java source code and directly produce module and source archives in a module repository.
The ceylonc command accepts a list of module names (without versions) or file paths, along with the following options:

listitem.para: -out specifies the output module repository (which must be publishable).
-src specifies a source directory.
-rep specifies a module repository containing dependencies.
-d disables the default module repositories and source directory.
-user sets the user name for the HTTP output repository.
-pass sets the password for the HTTP output repository.
-help displays a usage help page.
-version specifies the Ceylon version.

section.para: The default module repositories are modules and http://modules.ceylon-lang.org, and the default source directory is source. The default output module repository is modules.

comment.para: TODO: how do you create signed jars? Some additional commandline options?

section.para: The compiler searches for compilation units belonging to the specified modules in the specified source directories. For each specified module, the compiler generates a module archive, source archive, and their checksum files in the specified output module repository.
All program elements imported by a compilation unit must belong to the same module as the compilation unit, or must belong to a module that is explicitly imported in the module descriptor.
The compiler searches for dependencies in the following locations:

listitem.para: module archives in the specified repositories,
source archives in the specified repositories, and
module directories in the specified source directories.

section.title: The module info tool
section.para: The module info tool prints information about the contents of a module archive, its description, its licence, and its dependencies to the console.
The ceylonp command accepts a list of module names with optional versions, along with the following options:

listitem.para: -rep specifies a module repository.
-src specifies a source directory.
-d disables the default module repositories and source directory.

section.para: The default module repositories are modules and http://modules.ceylon-lang.org, and the default source directory is source.
The tool searches for modules in the following locations:

listitem.para: module archives in the specified repositories,
source archives in the specified repositories, and
module directories in the specified source directories.

section.para: If no version identifier is specified for a module, the tool prints information about all available versions of the module.

section.title: The documentation compiler
section.para: The documentation compiler generates XHTML-format documentation from Ceylon source files. The content of the doc annotations is treated as Markdown format text.
The ceylond command accepts a list of module names with optional versions, along with the following options:

listitem.para: -out specifies the output module repository (which must be publishable).
-src specifies a source directory.
-rep specifies a module repository containing source archives.
-non-shared includes documentation for package-private declarations.
-source-code includes source code in the generated documentation.
-d disables the default module repositories and source directory.
-user sets the user name for the HTTP output repository.
-pass sets the password for the HTTP output repository.
-help displays a usage help page.
-version specifies the Ceylon version.

section.para: The default module repositories are modules and http://modules.ceylon-lang.org, and the default source directory is source. The default output module repository is modules.

The documentation compiler searches for compilation units belonging to the specified modules in the specified source directories and in source archives in the specified module repositories. For each specified module, the compiler generates a set of XHTML pages in the module documentation directory (the module-doc directory) of the specified output module repository.
The compiler searches for source in the following locations:

listitem.para: source archives in the specified repositories, and
module directories in the specified source directories.

section.para: If no version identifier is specified for a module, the module is assumed to exist in a source directory.

section.title: The repository replicator
section.para: The repository replicator copies modules from one repository to another. For example, it may be used to create local copies of modules in remote repositories, or to publish modules to a remote repository.
To publish a module to http://modules.ceylon-lang.org, a module developer may use the repository replicator to submit the module via WebDAV.
The ceylonr command accepts a list of versioned module names, along with the following options:

listitem.para: -out specifies the output module repository (which must be publishable).
-rep specifies a module repository containing source archives.
-d disables the default module repositories.
-nosrc disables replication of source archives.
-nodoc disables replication of module documentation directories.

section.para: The default module repositories are modules and http://modules.ceylon-lang.org. The default output module repository is modules.

The repository replicator searches for directories containing the specified modules in the specified module repositories and, if found, replicates their contents into the specified output module repository.

section.title: The source archive extractor
section.para: The source archive extractor fetches source archives and extracts their contents into a source directory. This is especially useful for working with example projects.
The ceylonf command accepts a list of versioned module names, along with the following options:

listitem.para: -src specifies the output source directory.
-rep specifies a module repository containing source archives.
-d disables the default module repositories.

section.para: The default module repositories are modules and http://modules.ceylon-lang.org. The default output source directory is source.
The source archive extractor searches for source archives for the specified modules in the specified module repositories and, if found, extracts their contents into the specified source directory.

section.title: The JAR importer
section.para: The JAR import allows you to publish a Java JAR into a Ceylon repository so they can then be imported by Ceylon modules. This is very useful for interoperating with Java libraries.
The ceylon-import-jar command accepts a module name and version and a JAR file path, along with the following options:

listitem.para: -out specifies the output module repository (which must be publishable).
-d disables the default module repositories.
-user sets the user name for the HTTP output repository.
-pass sets the password for the HTTP output repository.
-help displays a usage help page.
-version specifies the Ceylon version.
-debug prints debugging information.

section.para: The default output module repository is modules.
The JAR importer imports a Java JAR as a Ceylon module into a Ceylon repository, so that it can by imported by Ceylon modules.
